facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1106 of 1964 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1106 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated October 31, 1961 of Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 67 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated the October 31, 1961 of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 67 of 1958.

facts.text: Appellant is India Cements Limited, Madras, a public limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, India Cements Limited, Madras, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, is a public limited companypany.

facts.text: Assessment year 1950-51, accounting period April 1, 1949 to March 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The question arises in respect of the assessment year 1950- 51, accounting period April 1, 1949 to March 31, 1950.

facts.text: Assessee obtained a loan of 40 lakhs of rupees from the Industrial Finance Corporation of India.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year it obtained a loan of 40 lakhs of rupees from the Industrial Finance Corporation of India.

facts.text: Loan secured by a charge on the fixed assets of the company.

anchor.surface_text: This loan was secured by a charge on the fixed assets of the companypany.

facts.text: Proceeds of loan utilised to pay off prior debt of 25 lakhs due to Messrs A. F. Harvey Limited and Madurai Mills, Limited.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated in the statement of the case that the proceeds of this loan was utilised to pay off a prior debt of 25 lakhs due to Messrs A. F. Harvey Limited and Madurai Mills, Limited.

facts.text: Balance of 15 lakhs utilised towards working funds as per directors' report dated 4-10-1949.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be stated definitely how the balance of 15 lakhs was used but the directors, while reporting on the accounts for the year ended 31-3-1949 on 4-10-1949 stated that that was utilised towards working funds.

facts.text: Expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- incurred in connection with this loan.

anchor.surface_text: The expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- in companynection with this loan was made up of thefollowing items

facts.text: Breakup of expenditure: Stamps 60,023; Registration Fee 16,067; Charges for certified copy 28; Indemnity deed 15; Vakils fee 7,500; Legal fees 1,000. Total Rs. 84,633.

anchor.surface_text: Stamps 60,02300 Registration Fee 16,,06700 Charges for certified companyy of the mortgage deed 2800 Indemnity deed by Essen and Company, Limited 1500 Vakils fee for drafting deed 7,50000 Legal fees 1,00000 Total Rs. 84,633 0 0

facts.text: Expenditure not charged in profits and loss account for that year, shown in Balance Sheet as mortgage loan expenses.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee did number charge this expenditure in the profits and loss account for that year. It was shown in the Balance Sheet as mortgage loan expenses.

facts.text: Expenditure continued to be shown in Balance Sheet till March 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It companytinued to be so shown till March 31, 1952.

facts.text: In accounts for March 31, 1953, expenditure written off by appropriation against profits of that year.

anchor.surface_text: In the accounts for March 31, 1953 this was written off by appropriation against the profits of that year.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer refused to allow deduction of Rs. 84,633/-, held it capital expenditure.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer refused to allow the deduction of Rs. 84,633/-. He observed As per the information furnished by the auditors, Rs. 25 lakhs of the loan was to be paid to Messrs A. F. Harvey, Limited, and Mathurai Mills, Limited in, discharge of the amount borrowed from them and utilised on the capital assets of the companypany.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held expenditure allowable, as loan for augmenting working funds.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal distinguished the case of Nagpur Electric Light and Power Co.  1  6 I.T.C. 28. Commissioner of Income Tax 1  on the ground that in the Nagpur Electric Light  1  case money was expended for obtaining capital. It observed as follows Here we find the position to be different. ... We, therefore, companysider that the whole of the mortgage loan was used firstly to discharge the loan of Rs. 25 lakhs and the balance for working funds and, as such, the whole of the amount was purely for the purposes of augmenting the working capital of the companypany

facts.text: Madras High Court answered question in favour of respondent, held expenditure capital.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras answering the following question of law in favour of the respondent

facts.text: High Court preferred findings of Income Tax Officer over Tribunal, as Tribunal inferred from balance-sheet without investigating use of prior 25 lakhs.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, after numbericing the findings of the Income Tax Officer and the Tribunal preferred the findings of fact made by the Income Tax Officer. ... the Tribunal does number appear to have been justified in relying upon inferences in ascertaining whether the earlier borrowal was on capital or revenue account.

facts.text: Prior 25 lakhs borrowed from Harvey and Madurai Mills utilised on capital assets, as per auditors' info to ITO.

anchor.surface_text: Though in the order of the Income- tax Officer it is found stated that that amount was utilised on the capital assets of the companypany and that statement was based on the authority of the information furnished by the auditors of the assessee

facts.text: Supreme Court holds expenditure is revenue expenditure, allowable under s.10(2)(xv), not capital.

anchor.surface_text: To companyclude we hold that the expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- was number in the nature of capital expenditure and was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessees business. The answer to the question referred, therefore, must be in the affirmative.

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court judgment set aside, question answered in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question referred answered in the affirmative.

facts.text: Paid-up capital sufficient to cover entire capital outlay as at 31-3-1949, per Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: A study of the balance-sheets of the companypany as at 31-3-1949 discloses the fact that the paid- up capital was sufficient to companyer the entire capital outlay of the companypany

facts.text: Mr. S. T. Desai disputed some facts as stated by the Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Since Mr. S. T. Desai, the learned companynsel for the respondent, has disputed some facts as stated by the Appellant Tribunal

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in law in holding that the sum of rupees 84,633/- expended by the assessee in obtaining the loan or any part thereof is an allowable expenditure?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was right in law in holding that the sum of rupees 84,633/- expended by the assessee in obtaining the loan or any part thereof is an allowable expenditure ?

holdings.text: the expenditure of Rs. 84,633/- was not in the nature of capital expenditure and was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the assessees business. The answer to the question referred, therefore, must be in the affirmative.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure for obtaining loan is revenue as it secures use of money for business period, not enduring asset; wholly for business per commercial expediency; object of loan irrelevant.

holdings.text: the loan obtained is not an asset or advantage of an enduring nature
holdings.reasoning_summary: Loan is liability to be repaid, not enduring benefit per Viscount Cave test; distinguished English cases on debenture issuance as capital.

holdings.text: the expenditure was made for securing the use of money for a certain period
holdings.reasoning_summary: Expenditure analogous to interest, procures use of funds like hire; applies principles from Coelho and Bombay Steam Navigation.

holdings.text: it is irrelevant to consider the object with which the loan was obtained
holdings.reasoning_summary: Purpose of loan use does not color expenditure nature; avoids uncertainty in actual vs intended use.

anchor.surface_text: With great respect we must hold that this case was wrongly decided. The Kerala High Court in Western India Plywood Ltd. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras 4 held that the expenditure

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nagpur Electric followed erroneous English/Tata cases treating loan raising as capital; Indian Act distinguishes.

holdings.text: In principle, apart from any statutory provisions, we see no distinction between interest in respect of a loan and an expenditure incurred for obtaining the loan

anchor.surface_text: In principle, apart from any statutory provisions, we see no distinction between interest in respect of a loan and an expenditure incurred for obtaining the loan. Mr. Desai urges that these

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both procure use of money for profit-making; interest deductible, so expenditure too; per Lord Atkinson.

holdings.text: in a reference the High Court must accept the findings of fact made by the Appellate Tribunal and it is for the person who has applied for a reference to challenge those findings first by an application under s. 66(1)
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement under s.66(1); not decided but opined.
